public class Canvas
extends com.google.gwt.user.client.ui.FocusWidget

The Canvas is a widget that you use to draw arbitrary graphics.

When you want to draw a shape, you set the current path to that shape and then paint the shape by stroking, filling, or both stroking and filling. Stroking is the process of painting a line along the current path. Filling is the process of painting the area contained within the path.

You use paths to draw both simple shapes (for example, lines, circles, or rectangles) and complex shapes (such as the silhouette of a mountain range) in a canvas. You can use a path to both draw the outline of a shape and fill the inside of a shape. Prior to building the path, you can define properties such as fillStyle or strokeStyle that can be used by drawing primitives to fill or stroke the path.

When you close the path, the canvas connects the end of the last line segment to the start of the first segment and terminates the current subpath. If you donâ€™t close the path by calling closePath before painting, the path is implicitly closed for you by drawing primitives that fill or clip (but it is not closed for stroking).

See Also:
http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Canvas_tutorial

Constructor Detail

Canvas

public Canvas()
Creates a canvas widget with an initial drawing area of 300x150 pixels.

It's background color is not set by default (it is transparent). The default CSS class selector is named gwt-Canvas. It may be used to apply additional style rules to the canvas widget.

Canvas

public Canvas(int width,
              int height)
Creates a canvas widget with the specified drawing area size.

It's background color is not set by default (it is transparent). The default CSS class selector is named gwt-Canvas. It may be used to apply additional style rules to the canvas widget.

Parameters:
width - the width of the canvas drawing area in pixels
height - the height of the canvas drawing area in pixels

Canvas

public Canvas(String width,
              String height)
Creates a canvas widget with the specified drawing area size.

It's background color is not set by default (it is transparent). The default CSS class selector is named gwt-Canvas. It may be used to apply additional style rules to the canvas widget.

Parameters:
width - the width of the canvas drawing area in CSS units
height - the height of the canvas drawing area in CSS units

getWidth

public int getWidth()
Returns the width of the canvas drawing area in pixels.

Unlike UIObject.getOffsetWidth() the returned value represents the width of the actual drawing area, excluding decorations such as border, margin, and padding.

Returns:
the width of the drawing area

Returns the height of the canvas drawing area in pixels.

Unlike UIObject.getOffsetHeight() the returned value represents the height of the actual drawing area, excluding decorations such as border, margin, and padding.

Returns:
the height of the drawing area

setBackgroundColor

public void setBackgroundColor(String color)
Sets the background color of the canvas widget.

You can set it in several different ways depending on the color space you intend to use. For web-safe colors, pass a web color specification string of the form "#RRGGBB", which represents an RGB color using hexadecimal numbers. If you want to make the background transparent, simply pass Canvas.TRANSPARENT as a parameter.

The widget's background color is not part of the drawing state.

Parameters:
color - "#RRGGBB" to specify a color or Canvas.TRANSPARENT if a transparent background is needed

getBackgroundColor

public String getBackgroundColor()
Returns the current background color of the canvas.

If the canvas background is transparent, Canvas.TRANSPARENT will be returned.

Returns:
the current background color or Canvas.TRANSPARENT

restore

public void restore()
Restores the current graphics state to the state most recently saved.

If you wish to save the settings of the current drawing environment, that is, the current graphics state, you can call the save() method. When you call save(), the canvas saves the current graphics state to the top of the graphics state stack.

To restore your drawing environment to a previously saved state, you can use this method. When you call restore(), the canvas removes the most recently saved graphics state from the top of the stack and uses that stateâ€™s saved settings for the current graphics state.

save

public void save()
Saves a copy of the current graphics state.

The graphics state contains data describing the current drawing environment. Methods that draw to the canvas use the graphics state settings to determine how to render their results.

Each canvas maintains a stack of graphics states. If you wish to save the settings of the current drawing environment, that is, the current graphics state, you can call the save() method. When you call save(), the canvas object saves the current graphics state to the top of the graphics state stack.

To restore your drawing environment to a previously saved state, you can use the restore() method. When you call restore(), the canvas removes the most recently saved graphics state from the top of the stack and uses that stateâ€™s saved settings for the current graphics state.

Note that not all aspects of the current drawing environment are elements of the graphics state. For example, the current path is not considered part of the graphics state and is therefore not saved when you call this method.

rotate

public void rotate(double angle)
Rotates the user coordinate system of the canvas.

The current transformation matrix (CTM) specifies the mapping from device-independent user space coordinates to a device space. By modifying the CTM, you can modify (scale, translate, rotate) the objects you draw. Itâ€™s important to note the order of events necessary to transform an object in a graphics context. Prior to drawing the object, you must first transform the coordinate space of the context (by calling this method), and then draw the object.

For example, to rotate an image, you must call this method to rotate the coordinate space of the context before drawing the image. When you draw the image, the canvas draws to the window using the rotated coordinate system. You specify both the magnitude and direction of the rotation by specifying an angle of adjustment in radians.

To restore the previous coordinate space, you must save the graphics state before modifying the CTM, and restore the graphics state after drawing.

Parameters:
angle - specifies the amount of coordinate-space rotation and is measured in radians

scale

public void scale(double x,
                  double y)
Changes the scale of the canvas coordinate system.

The current transformation matrix (CTM) specifies the mapping from device independent user space coordinates to a device space. By modifying the CTM, you can modify (scale, translate, rotate) the objects you draw. It is important to note the order of events necessary to transform an object in a graphics context. Prior to drawing the object, you must first transform the coordinate space of the context (by calling this method), and then draw the object.

Scaling operations modify the x- and y-coordinates by a given scaling factor. The magnitude of the x and y factors governs whether the new coordinates are larger or smaller than the original. For example, specifying the value 2.0 for the x parameter causes subsequently drawn objects to appear at twice their specified width. In addition, by making the x factor negative, you can flip the coordinates about the y-axis; similarly, you can flip coordinates about the x-axis by making the y factor negative.

To restore the previous coordinate space, you must save the graphics state before modifying the CTM, and restore the graphics state after drawing.

Parameters:
x - contains a double value with the x-axis scale factor
y - contains a double value with the y-axis scale factor

translate

public void translate(double x,
                      double y)
Changes the origin of the canvas coordinate system.

The current transformation matrix (CTM) specifies the mapping from device-independent user space coordinates to a device space. By modifying the CTM, you can modify (scale, translate, rotate) the objects you draw. Itâ€™s important to note the order of events necessary to transform an object in a graphics context. Prior to drawing the object, you must first transform the coordinate space of the page (by calling this method), and then draw the object.

This method displaces the x- and y-axes (thus, the origin) of the coordinate system by the values you specify. When you draw into this adjusted coordinate space, the x- and y-coordinates of your drawing are also displaced.

To restore the previous coordinate space, you must save the graphics state before modifying the CTM, and restore the graphics state after drawing.

Parameters:
x - contains a double value with the x-axis translation value
y - contains a double value with the y-axis translation value

arc

public void arc(double x,
                double y,
                double radius,
                double startAngle,
                double endAngle,
                boolean antiClockwise)
Adds an arc of a circle to the current subpath.

The arc is built based on the circle whose origin and radius are specified by the x, y, and radius parameters. The startAngle parameter specifies the angle of the starting point of the arc, measured in radians from the positive x-axis. The endAngle parameter specifies the angle of the endpoint of the arc, measured in radians from the positive x-axis. Specify false for the anticlockwise parameter to draw the arc in a clockwise direction; otherwise specify true.

If the current path already contains a subpath, the canvas appends a straight line segment from the current point to the starting point of the arc. If the current path is empty, the canvas creates a new subpath for the arc and does not add an initial line segment. After adding the arc, the current point is set to the endpoint of the arc.

Parameters:
x -
y -
radius -
startAngle -
endAngle -
anticlockwise -

cubicCurveTo

public void cubicCurveTo(double cp1x,
                         double cp1y,
                         double cp2x,
                         double cp2y,
                         double x,
                         double y)
Appends a cubic BÃ©zier curve to the current path.

A cubic curve segment has a start point, two control points, and an endpoint. The start point is the current endpoint of the open path. The cp1x, cp1y, cp2x, and cp2y parameters specify the two control points for the path. The x and y parameters specify the new endpoint for the path. After adding the segment, the current point is reset from the beginning of the new segment to the endpoint of that segment.

Parameters:
cp1x -
cp1y -
cp2x -
cp2y -
x -
y -

quadraticCurveTo

public void quadraticCurveTo(double cpx,
                             double cpy,
                             double x,
                             double y)
Appends a quadratic BÃ©zier curve to the current path.

A quadratic curve segment has a start point, one control point, and an endpoint. The start point is the current point of the canvas. The cpx and cpy parameters specify the control point. The x and y parameters specify the new endpoint. After adding the segment, the current point is reset from the beginning of the new segment to the endpoint of that segment.

Parameters:
cpx -
cpy -
x -
y -

beginPath

public void beginPath()
Creates a new empty path in the canvas.

You use paths to draw both simple shapes (for example, lines, circles, or rectangles) and complex shapes (such as the silhouette of a mountain range) in a canvas. You can use a path to both draw the outline of a shape and fill the inside of a shape.

Before painting a shape, you must create the shape to be painted using the current path. You build a path from a set of subpaths, each of which is a list of one or more segments, either straight lines or curves.

A canvas can have only a single path in use at any time. Therefore, if the specified context already contains a current path when you call this method, the canvas replaces the previous current path with the new path. In this case, the canvas discards the old path and any data associated with it.

Note: The current path is not part of the graphics state. Consequently, saving and restoring the graphics state has no effect on the current path.

closePath

public void closePath()
Closes and terminates an open subpath.

When a subpath is open and you call this method, the canvas closes the subpath (draws a straight line that connects the current point to the starting point), and terminates the subpath (the current point is no longer defined).

If no subpath is open, calling this method does nothing.

Note: You can stroke along an open subpath. When a subpath is open and you fill, however, the canvas implicitly closes the subpath for you.

moveTo

public void moveTo(double x,
                   double y)
Begins a new subpath at the point you specify.

Before painting a shape in the canvas, you must create the shape to be painted using the current path. You build a path from a set of subpaths, each of which is a list of one or more segments, either straight lines or curves.

This method begins a newsubpath starting at the point you specify with the x and y parameters. This point is defined to be the "current" point, and it defines the starting point of the next line segment. The canvas sets the current point in one of two ways:

  • Explicitly, when you call this method to begin a new subpath at a given point
  • Implicitly, when you add a new curve or straight line segment to the subpath; after adding the segment, the current point is reset from the beginning of the new segment to the endpoint of that segment

Parameters:
x -
y -

lineTo

public void lineTo(double x,
                   double y)
Appends a straight line segment from the current point to the point you specify.

You can use straight line segments, cubic and quadratic BÃ©zier curve segments, and rectangles to specify a path. You can append a single straight line segment to the current subpath using this method. After adding the line segment, the current point is reset from the beginning of the new line segment to the endpoint of that line segment, as specified by the x and y parameters.

Parameters:
x -
y -

rect

public void rect(double x,
                 double y,
                 double w,
                 double h)
Adds a new subpath consisting of a single rectangle to the canvas.

The parameters of this method all contain double values.

Parameters:
x -
y -
w -
h -

clear

public void clear()
Clears the entire canvas.

When you call this method, the canvas effectively "erases" all of it's contents, if any.

fill

public void fill()
Paints the area within the current path.

The fill color is an attribute of the graphics state. You can set the current fill color by setting a value with the setFillStyle(String) method.

When you fill the current path, the canvas fills each subpath independently. Any subpath that has not been explicitly closed is closed implicitly by the fill routines.

stroke

public void stroke()
Paints a line along the current path.

To modify the behavior of this method, you can change any of the following graphics state properties with these methods:

  • setLineWidth(double)
  • setLineJoin(String)
  • setLineCap(String)
  • setMiterLimit(double)
  • setStrokeStyle(String)
  • setGlobalAlpha(double)

fillRect

public void fillRect(double x,
                     double y,
                     double w,
                     double h)
Paints the area within the specified rectangle.

This method uses the current fill color to paint the area of the specified rectangle. The parameters of this method all contain double values.

As a side effect of calling this method, the canvas clears the current path.

Parameters:
x -
y -
w -
h -

strokeRect

public void strokeRect(double x,
                       double y,
                       double w,
                       double h)
Paints an outline of a rectangle.

This method uses the current stroke color to paint the path represented by the specified rectangle. The parameters of this method all contain double values.

To alter the appearance of the painted outline, you can modify the following attributes of the graphics state:

  • setLineWidth(double)
  • setLineJoin(String)
  • setLineCap(String)
  • setMiterLimit(double)
  • setStrokeStyle(String)
  • setGlobalAlpha(double)

Parameters:
x -
y -
w -
h -

createLinearGradient

public Gradient createLinearGradient(double x0,
                                     double y0,
                                     double x1,
                                     double y1)
Returns a gradient object representing a linear gradient.

Use Gradient.addColorStop(double, String) to add colors and offsets to a gradient. The 0 offset in this case is the start of the gradient (x0, y0) while the 1 offset is the end of the gradient (x1, y1).

The returned object can be assigned to the setFillStyle(Gradient) and #setStrokeStyle(Gradient) methods.

Parameters:
x0 -
y0 -
x1 -
y1 -
Returns:
an object that represents a linear gradient between the two input coordinates

createRadialGradient

public Gradient createRadialGradient(double x0,
                                     double y0,
                                     double r0,
                                     double x1,
                                     double y1,
                                     double r1)
Returns a gradient object representing a radial gradient.

Use Gradient.addColorStop(double, String) to add colors and offsets to a gradient. The 0 offset in this case is the circumference of the first circle (x0, y0, r0) while the 1 offset is the circumference of the second circle (x1, y1, r1).

The returned object can be assigned to the setFillStyle(Gradient) and #setStrokeStyle(Gradient) methods.

Parameters:
x0 -
y0 -
r0 -
x1 -
y1 -
r1 -
Returns:
an object that represents a radial gradient between the edges of two circles using the input coordinates and the radii

drawImage

public void drawImage(Image image,
                      double x,
                      double y)
Draws an image in the specified rectangle.

This method is overloaded with three variants, used to draw the contents of an Image object into the canvas.

Draws the image at the x and y coordinates within the canvas. The image is sized as it is in the object.

Parameters:
image -
x -
y -

drawImage

public void drawImage(Image image,
                      double x,
                      double y,
                      double width,
                      double height)
Draws an image in the specified rectangle.

This method is overloaded with three variants, used to draw the contents of an Image object into the canvas.

The x, y, width, and height parameters contain values representing the bounding rectangle for the image. These values are specified in the coordinate system of the canvas. If the specified coordinates lie outside of the canvas bounds, the image will be clipped.

Parameters:
image -
x -
y -
width -
height -

drawImage

public void drawImage(Image image,
                      double sx,
                      double sy,
                      double sWidth,
                      double sHeight,
                      double dx,
                      double dy,
                      double dWidth,
                      double dHeight)
Draws an image in the specified rectangle.

This method is overloaded with three variants, used to draw the contents of an Image object into the canvas.

Draws the portion of the image specified by the source rectangle ( sx, sy, sWidth, sHeight) onto the canvas at the specified destination rectangle (dx, dy, dWidth, dHeight). The source rectangle is specified in the image coordinate space and the destination rectangle is specified in the canvas coordinate space.

Parameters:
image -
sx -
sy -
sWidth -
sHeight -
dx -
dy -
dWidth -
dHeight -

setGlobalAlpha

public void setGlobalAlpha(double globalAlpha)
A double value indicating the alpha channel value, which determines the opacity of content drawn on the canvas. The range of values is between 0.0 (fully transparent) and 1.0 (no additional transparency). By default, this parameterâ€™s value is 1.0 (no transparency).

The canvas uses the alpha value in the current graphics state to determine how to composite newly painted objects.

Parameters:
globalAlpha - the global alpha channel value (range 0.0 to 1.0)

getGlobalAlpha

public double getGlobalAlpha()
See setter method setGlobalAlpha(double) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
the global alpha channel value (range 0.0 to 1.0)

setGlobalCompositeOperation

public void setGlobalCompositeOperation(String globalCompositeOperation)
Determines how the canvas contents are displayed relative to any existing content. The string identifies the desired compositing mode. If you do not set this value explicitly, the canvas uses the Canvas.SOURCE_OVER compositing setting by default.

Parameters:
globalCompositeOperation - Canvas.SOURCE_OVER or Canvas.DESTINATION_OVER

getGlobalCompositeOperation

public String getGlobalCompositeOperation()
See setter method setGlobalCompositeOperation(String) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
Canvas.SOURCE_OVER or Canvas.DESTINATION_OVER

setStrokeStyle

public void setStrokeStyle(String strokeStyle)
The color the canvas applies when stroking paths. When you set this property, the canvas sets the stroke style parameter of the graphics state.

You can set it in several different ways depending on the color space you intend to use. For web-safe colors, pass a web color specification string of the form "#RRGGBB", which represents an RGB color using hexadecimal numbers.

If you want the shape stroke to have an alpha value, use the CSS rgba(r, g, b, alpha) functional-notation style. Use integer values between 0 and 255 for the r, g, and b parameters. The alpha parameter contains a double value, between 0.0 and 1.0, indicating the alpha channel value, which determines the opacity of the color.

Parameters:
strokeStyle - a String representing the stroke color

getStrokeStyle

public String getStrokeStyle()
See setter methods setStrokeStyle(String) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
a color String object representing the stroke style

setFillStyle

public void setFillStyle(Gradient fillStyle)
The style the canvas applies when filling paths. When you set this property, the canvas sets the fill style parameter of the graphics state.

You can set the fill style to be a linear or radial gradient. Use the createLinearGradient(double, double, double, double) and createRadialGradient(double, double, double, double, double, double) methods to define a style that you can apply to this method.

Parameters:
fillStyle - a Gradient representing the fill style

setFillStyle

public void setFillStyle(String fillStyle)
The color the canvas applies when filling paths. When you set this property, the canvas sets the fill style parameter of the graphics state.

You can set it in several different ways depending on the color space you intend to use. For web-safe colors, pass a web color specification string of the form "#RRGGBB", which represents an RGB color using hexadecimal numbers.

If you want the shape fill to have an alpha value, use the CSS rgba(r, g, b, alpha) functional-notation style. Use integer values between 0 and 255 for the r, g, and b parameters. The alpha parameter contains a double value, between 0.0 and 1.0, indicating the alpha channel value, which determines the opacity of the color.

Parameters:
fillStyle - a String representing the fill color

getFillStyle

public Object getFillStyle()
See setter methods setFillStyle(String) and setFillStyle(Gradient) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
a color String or Gradient object representing the fill style

setLineWidth

public void setLineWidth(double lineWidth)
A double value indicating the line width for drawing operations. This value must be greater than zero. You can affect the width of lines and curves that the canvas draws by modifying the line width property of the graphics state. The line width is the total width of the line, expressed in units of the user space. The line surrounds the center of the path, with half of the total width on either side.

Parameters:
lineWidth - the line width

getLineWidth

public double getLineWidth()
See setter method setLineWidth(double) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
the line width

setLineCap

public void setLineCap(String lineCap)
A string value that determines the end style used when drawing a line. If you do not set this value explicitly, the canvas uses the Canvas.BUTT line cap style.

Parameters:
lineCap - Canvas.BUTT, Canvas.ROUND or Canvas.SQUARE

getLineCap

public String getLineCap()
See setter method setLineCap(String) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
Canvas.BUTT, Canvas.ROUND or Canvas.SQUARE

setLineJoin

public void setLineJoin(String lineJoin)
A string value that determines the join style between lines. If you do not set this value explicitly, the canvas uses the Canvas.MITER line join style.

Parameters:
lineJoin - Canvas.ROUND, Canvas.BEVEL or Canvas.MITER

getLineJoin

public String getLineJoin()
See setter method setLineJoin(String) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
Canvas.ROUND, Canvas.BEVEL or Canvas.MITER

setMiterLimit

public void setMiterLimit(double miterLimit)
A double value with the new miter limit. You use this property to specify how the canvas draws the juncture between connected line segments. If the line join is set to Canvas.MITER, the canvas uses the miter limit to determine whether the lines should be joined with a bevel instead of a miter. The canvas divides the length of the miter by the line width. If the result is greater than the miter limit, the style is converted to a bevel.

Parameters:
miterLimit - the miter limit

getMiterLimit

public double getMiterLimit()
See setter method setMiterLimit(double) for a fully detailed description.

Returns:
the miter limit

setShadow

                      int blur,
                      int offsetX,
                      int offsetY)
Sets the canvas shadow

Parameters:
color - The color of the shadow as a CSS string
blur - The blur distance
offsetX - The horizontal offset of the shadow
offsetY - The vertical offset of the shadow
